content: My son, Jerry, had an unique opportunity to play Tiny Tim in the Sonder Theatre Company‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Christmas Carol‚Äù show.  It is the best Christmas gift that I‚Äôve ever received.  #ProudDad https://t.co/IZedcjIedw

My Stanford roommate and I were discussing whether we needed liquid immersion cooling (which immerses extremely hot electronic parts in a thermally, but not electrically, conductive liquid to cool them) back in 2003 - which I thought was unnecessary at the time because I believed that efficient computing would mitigate the need for such a complicated scheme.  I finally saw such a computer in real life in 2024.  

The liquid is actually a kind of special oil that feels like a baby oil.

Congratulations to @SashaReneePerez for winning the California State Senate race and representing our community in Sacramento üéâ  I still could not believe that our state senator is 10 years younger than me üòÇ https://t.co/v7gXp1C7db

Simone Ravaoli, Ildiko Mazar, and @codenamedmitri presented on "VC EDU Task Force Updates" at W3C CCG.  VC EDU is a popular task force under CCG that meets every Monday to work on education-related applications of verifiable credentials, such as verifiable credentials revocation, European digital micro-credentials, LERs (Learning and Employment Records), and Open Badges 3.0.  You can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 4 min 10 sec mark): https://t.co/9ZTKA04vWa

Heather Flanagan presented on "Federated Identity Working Group Updates" at W3C CCG.  She first started with the original story of Federated Credential Manager API #FedCM.  She then talked about Digital Credentials API and how it differs from Federated Credential Management API.  While both Digital Credentials API and FedCM can help advance self-sovereign identity, FedCM started with the browsers, and Digital Credentials API deals with digital wallets, and they can have different privacy properties.  You can view Heather‚Äôs presentation deck here:  https://t.co/qTx681U2C1  And you can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 11 min 10 sec mark): https://t.co/muDgRl9b2Q

We had our quarterly W3C CCG work item updates and open discussion.  We went through the latest developments in VC-API, VC 2.0 Test Suite, Quantum Safe Data Integrity Signature Suite, VC Education, VC Traceability, VC Render Method, VC Barcodes, Verifiable Issuers and Verifiers, and DID Linked Resources.  You can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 14 min 50 sec mark): https://t.co/v0Kb5EuNtB

We are searching for experienced software developers, data engineers, and product managers to help us build industry-leading identity solutions.  If you are interested in solving the problem of ‚Äúwho we are‚Äù or playing with cutting-edge technology, please join us here:  https://t.co/4U5dPRTTyp

Zo√´ Hitzig and Steven Adler from @OpenAI presented on "Personhood Credentials: A Privacy-Preserving Credential to Demonstrate Who's Real Online, Amid Artificial Intelligence" at W3C CCG.  It‚Äôs getting harder to tell if someone on the Internet is real or not, and personhood credentials #PHC leans into two things that AI cannot do to solve this problem:  (1) physical, real-world components, and (2) cryptography.  You can read the paper here:  https://t.co/N89pTkdcfl  And you can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 9 min 15 sec mark): https://t.co/o3DCBao2XF

Excited to share this whitepaper, Data Accuracy in the Age of AI. As AI transforms our digital world, ensuring data accuracy has become essential. Drawing on my experiences as Spokeo‚Äôs CEO, I‚Äôve highlighted key challenges in managing data and the strategies that can be used to address them.
https://t.co/NpCQjkJYU7
Proud to sponsor the Internet Identity Workshop #IIW 39 - my favorite conference üòç https://t.co/oA9KF7IkDE
RT @elonmusk: Must be a coincidence üôÑ https://t.co/npsMqqatx0
Must be a coincidence üôÑ https://t.co/npsMqqatx0

Wolf McNally and Christopher Allen from Blockchain Commons presented on "Gordian Envelope, Elision, and Controller Documents" at W3C CCG.  Gordian envelope is a smart document system built on deterministic CBOR, and it consists of triples of subject, predicate, and object.  It supports elision or hiding of data while preserving verifiability.  Wolf and Christopher also introduced their latest Gordian Sealed Transaction Protocol that leverages the Gordian envelope for use cases like key agreement, data exchange, confidential backups, and multi-signature coordination.  You can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here: https://t.co/5itnsJwst3  You can also view the transcription of the discussion here:  https://t.co/7uEas3hDjw
We need more monetization discussions at #IIW and in #SSI üòÄ.  Monetization is critical to driving market adoption.

@ACLU ‚ÄúHow to make money ü§ë from SSI‚Äù, a session convened by @tang_talks. A lot of talk about how regulation is opening up the industry, and locking up credentials doesn‚Äôt work‚Ä¶but monetising other aspects around credential exchange does. https://t.co/Oer4agyZwW

Denis "Jaromil" Roio and Andrea D'Intino from https://t.co/Br5WcakMwQ presented and led a great discussion on "BBS+ Signature Scheme Benchmarks" at W3C CCG.  In sum, BBS+ signature performs well.  It takes less than 1 second for thousand credential presentations and almost 1.5 second for thousand credential verifications.  BBS+ public keys are 96 bytes; its signatures are 80 bytes; and its zero-knowledge proofs are 272 bytes.  Interestingly, the more information you hide, the bigger the BBS+ proof.  Lastly ,the encoding of the BBS+ proof appears as random data.  You can read more about their research here: https://t.co/aukxVbfBcZ  And you can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 12-min mark): https://t.co/fFRV3cTriw

Giuseppe Tropea and Martin Bauer, Vice-Chairs of #ETSI #ISG #CIM, presented on "NGSI-LD - Signing NGSI-LD and Authentication in NGSI-LD" at W3C CCG.  #NGSI-LD (Next Generation Service Interfaces - Linked Data) is an information model for context information that enables applications to specify what information they require.  Its federated architecture allows context consumers (e.g. applications) to federate distributed context information from multiple sources and producers.  Giuseppe and Martin talked about how they leverage digital signatures, data integrity suite, and DID authentication to ensure that different context information from different sources can be secured and trusted.  You can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 5-min 10-sec mark): https://t.co/ifvRJ4nzs0

Wayne Chang, co-founder and CEO of @SpruceID  and former co-chair of W3C CCG, presented on "Provably Forgotten Signatures".  #Linkability can happen when traceable digital signatures or identifiers are used repeatedly, such as in verifier-verifier collusion and issuer-verifier collusion cases.  Zero-knowledge proofs like BBS signatures can be used to prevent such linkability, but there are still production challenges to their adoption today.  Wayne proposed a more pragmatic approach that leverages the hardware‚Äôs Trusted Execution Environments, so issuers don‚Äôt need to retain signatures and won‚Äôt be able to link them later.  You can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 10-min mark): https://t.co/NWmb3a4ZXi

Andrew Trask presented on "OpenMined and the Future of AI Infrastructure" at W3C CCG.  OpenMined https://t.co/Qg0VPXGcAe is an open-source community whose goal is to make the world more privacy-preserving by lowering the barrier to entry to private AI technologies, and they have developed tools like PySyft https://t.co/Yr7yCNsZJF that leverage federated learning https://t.co/kNVwsAeWtH to perform data science in a privacy-preserving way.

Andrew explained that the goal of privacy-enhancing technologies #PETs is to answer a question using data owned by someone else, and they can roughly be grouped into 4 types:  (1) Input privacy technologies like secure enclave, functional encryption, homomorphic encryption, multi-party computation, and federated learning, (2) Input verification technologies like cryptographic signatures and zero-knowledge proofs, (3) Output privacy technologies like K-anonymization, differential privacy, and synthetic data, and (4) Output verification technologies like active security.

Lastly, Andrew highlighted 4 tools in Pysyft:  (1) Remote execution, (2) Example and mock data, (3) Differential privacy that ensures statistical analysis doesn‚Äôt compromise privacy, (4) Secure multi-party computation #MPC.    You can watch the recording of the presentation and discussion here (start at 7-min mark): https://t.co/7hPO45X7aJ
